summary: This document is an email chain from November 2021 between federal prosecutors in the Southern District of New York and Dr. Gail Goodman, a Distinguished Professor of Psychology at UC Davis, regarding her potential role as an expert witness in the trial of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails discuss scheduling a call and include Dr. Goodman's background information and research on memory, particularly related to child sexual abuse.

persons.name: Gail Goodman
persons.role: Expert Witness / Distinguished Professor of Psychology
persons.context: A Distinguished Professor at UC Davis being contacted by prosecutors to potentially consult and testify as an expert witness on memory, particularly regarding child sexual abuse, in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, which is the subject of the prosecutors' outreach for an expert witness.

connections.description: Dr. Goodman is being considered as an expert witness for the prosecution in the criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Scheduled Start of Maxwell Trial
events.description: The trial of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled to begin on this date in the Southern District of New York.

keyFacts: Federal prosecutors from the Southern District of New York were actively seeking an expert witness for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial in late November 2021.
The prosecution contacted Dr. Gail Goodman, a Distinguished Professor specializing in psychology and memory research, particularly regarding child sexual abuse.

Dr. Goodman's research includes findings that misinformation can sometimes make memory for significant personal events more accurate, a point she highlighted as potentially useful for the prosecution's work.
The email chain shows coordination to schedule a call between Dr. Goodman and the prosecutors, indicating the late-stage preparation for the trial.
Dr. Goodman noted she had previously testified for the prosecution in federal court trials but never for the defense.
